description: From Middle English colt, from Old English colt, from Proto-Germanic *kultaz (“plump; stump; thick shape, bulb”), from Proto-Indo-European *gelt- (“something round, pregnant belly, child in the womb”), from *gel- (“to ball up, amass”). Cognate with Faroese koltur (“colt, foal”) Norwegian kult (“treestump”), Swedish kult (“young boar, boy, lad”). Related to child.

definitionGroups.group: (figuratively) A youthful or inexperienced person; a novice.

entries.meaning: (cricket, slang) A professional cricketer during his first season.
examples: The bowling is more promising in the colts than in the eleven.

entries.meaning: (nautical) A short piece of rope once used by petty officers as an instrument of punishment.

verbs.description: colt (third-person singular simple present colts, present participle colting, simple past and past participle colted)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To horse; to get with young.
To frisk or frolic like a colt; to act licentiously or wantonly.
